Ongoing research touches on several important areas of biomedical science including the molecular basis of disease, cancer biology and immunology. Member laboratories are situated within each of the major research buildings within the NYU Langone Medical Center Campus. Major infectious diseases in humans, including the methods used for their identification in the clinical lab, will be covered. Modes of transmission are described, as well as treatments and prevention. Application of the principles of microbiology to the work of health professionals will also be discussed. Microbiology & Immunology    | Department of Biology | New York University                                  NEW YORK UNIVERSITY     ARTS AND SCIENCE     COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE     GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE             Department of Biology     Arts & Science                    Back to Home       Microbiology & Immunology   Potential topics for graduate study in microbiology include Microbial Genomics of spore formation (B. subtilis). Research opportunities in microbiology include the study of the environmental effects caused by genetically engineered microorganisms. Studies in immunology range from innate to specific immunity, with specific research projects that examine tobacco-mediated changes in expression of Class I MHC molecules and the role of gamma-delta T cells in oral diseases. Other projects include the study of inflammatory responses to viral infections, regulation of the blood brain barrier, neuroimmunology, and immunological interactions between tumors and host tissues. The ultimate goal of much of this research is to design novel modalities for the treatment of viral infections and cancer.
